title: Add git SSH signing config to Darwin entrypoint
description:
Modify lib/sandbox/darwin/entrypoint.sh to configure git SSH signing using the deploy key.

Add after the SSH config setup (after line 109):
```bash
# Configure git SSH signing using deploy key
if [ -n "${WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY:-}" ] && [ -f "$WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY" ]; then
  git config --global gpg.format ssh
  git config --global user.signingkey "$WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY"
  # Create allowed_signers for signature verification
  mkdir -p "$HOME/.config/git"
  ssh-keygen -y -f "$WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY" > "$WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY.pub.tmp" 2>/dev/null || true
  if [ -f "$WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY.pub.tmp" ]; then
    echo "$GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL $(cat $WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY.pub.tmp)" > "$HOME/.config/git/allowed_signers"
    rm "$WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY.pub.tmp"
    git config --global gpg.ssh.allowedSignersFile "$HOME/.config/git/allowed_signers"
  fi
fi

# Enable auto-signing if requested
if [ "${WRAPIX_GIT_SIGN:-}" = "1" ] || [ "${WRAPIX_GIT_SIGN:-}" = "true" ]; then
  git config --global commit.gpgsign true
fi
```

title: Fix Darwin container networking with Tailscale exit node
description:
## Problem

Container networking fails when Tailscale is using an exit node. TCP connections timeout while ICMP (ping) works.

## Root Cause

1. Apple container CLI uses vmnet for networking (192.168.64.0/24 subnet)
2. When Tailscale exit node is enabled, ALL traffic routes through Tailscale
3. Container traffic from 192.168.64.x goes to exit node, but exit node can't NAT responses back to that private IP
4. "Allow Local Network Access" in Tailscale only covers physical LAN, not vmnet's virtual network

## Diagnosis Steps Performed

1. Confirmed networking works with Tailscale off
2. Confirmed ping works but TCP fails with Tailscale on (exit node intercepts TCP)
3. Confirmed MTU adjustment doesn't help (tried 1220)
4. Confirmed this is NOT an NSS/DNS issue - added fakeNss, glibc, resolv.conf correctly
5. Checked Apple container GitHub issues - found #345 (VPN/MTU issues) and #919 (Local Network Privacy)

## Previous Solution (Removed in bcec832)

The custom Swift runner used gvproxy (gvisor-tap-vsock) for userspace networking:
- Connected VM to gvproxy via VZFileHandleNetworkDeviceAttachment
- gvproxy handled NAT in userspace, traffic appeared from host IP
- Host IP is recognized by Tailscale, so routing worked correctly

This was removed when migrating to Apple container CLI, which manages vmnet internally and doesn't allow custom network attachments.

## Proposed Solutions

### Option 1: HTTP Proxy on Host (Recommended)
- Run tinyproxy/mitmproxy on host bound to 192.168.64.1:8080
- Set HTTP_PROXY/HTTPS_PROXY in container pointing to gateway
- Traffic: Container → Proxy → Host network (Tailscale) → Exit node → Internet
- Pros: Simple, works with current architecture
- Cons: Proxy config needed, some tools don't respect proxy vars

### Option 2: SOCKS Proxy via SSH Tunnel
- Create SSH tunnel to exit node: ssh -D 1080 exit-node
- Configure container to use SOCKS proxy
- Similar to Option 1 but uses SSH instead of HTTP proxy

### Option 3: Revert to Custom Swift Runner
- Re-add the Swift runner from before bcec832
- Use gvproxy for networking as before
- Pros: Transparent networking, no proxy config
- Cons: Maintains separate code path, more complex

### Option 4: Tailscale Inside Container
- Run Tailscale daemon inside container
- Container joins tailnet directly
- Pros: Full Tailscale features in container
- Cons: Auth complexity, resource overhead

## Files Changed (Investigation)

- lib/sandbox/image.nix: Added fakeNss, glibc, NSS symlinks, resolv.conf
- lib/sandbox/darwin/default.nix: Added --dns 1.1.1.1
- lib/tests/*.nix: Added --dns 1.1.1.1

## Files to Change (Fix)

For Option 1 (HTTP Proxy):
- lib/sandbox/darwin/default.nix: Start proxy, add HTTP_PROXY env vars
- lib/sandbox/darwin/proxy.nix: New file for tinyproxy package/config
- flake.nix: Add tinyproxy dependency

## Related

- GitHub issue: https://github.com/apple/container/issues/345
- Commit that removed gvproxy: bcec832
close_reason: Fixed by disabling 'Allow Local Network Access' in Tailscale settings. When this option is off, vmnet traffic routes correctly through the exit node.

title: Build NixOS podman machine image using darwin.linux-builder
description:
## Goal
Create a NixOS-based podman machine to replace the default Fedora CoreOS machine for native Nix linux-builder support.

## Background
- Podman machine on macOS uses Apple Hypervisor (vfkit), not QEMU
- Default podman machine runs Fedora CoreOS
- We need a NixOS image compatible with vfkit for native Nix builds

## Prerequisites
- darwin.linux-builder from nixpkgs (QEMU-based, pre-built from cache)
- Path: /nix/store/smc5avq1kxn465iz27ihs4g2da7lkbhd-create-builder

## Plan

### Phase 1: Bootstrap with darwin.linux-builder
1. Start the darwin.linux-builder (QEMU VM on port 31022)
2. Configure as Nix remote builder in /etc/nix/machines
3. Verify aarch64-linux builds work

### Phase 2: Build NixOS podman-compatible image
4. Create NixOS configuration for vfkit/Apple Hypervisor:
   - Use raw-efi disk format
   - Uncompressed aarch64 kernel (required for Apple VF)
   - virtio drivers for block, net, console
   - virtiofs support for host mounts (/Users, /private, /var/folders)
   - SSH server for remote access
   - Nix daemon pre-configured

5. Build the image using darwin.linux-builder:
   ```bash
   nix build --system aarch64-linux .#nixos-podman-image
   ```

### Phase 3: Create podman machine with NixOS
6. Stop existing podman machine: `podman machine stop`
7. Remove old machine: `podman machine rm podman-machine-default`
8. Create new machine with NixOS image:
   ```bash
   podman machine init --image-path /path/to/nixos.raw nixos-builder
   ```
9. Start and configure: `podman machine start nixos-builder`

### Phase 4: Configure as Nix remote builder
10. Configure SSH access to podman machine
11. Add to /etc/nix/machines with appropriate settings
12. Test linux builds work via podman machine

## NixOS Configuration Template

```nix
{ config, lib, pkgs, modulesPath, ... }:
{
  imports = [ (modulesPath + "/profiles/qemu-guest.nix") ];

  # Boot configuration for Apple Hypervisor
  boot = {
    loader.grub.efiSupport = true;
    loader.grub.efiInstallAsRemovable = true;
    loader.grub.device = "nodev";
    initrd.kernelModules = [ "virtio_pci" "virtio_blk" ];
    # Uncompressed kernel for Apple VF
    kernelParams = [ "console=ttyAMA0,115200n8" ];
  };

  # Filesystem layout
  fileSystems."/" = { device = "/dev/vda2"; fsType = "ext4"; };
  fileSystems."/boot" = { device = "/dev/vda1"; fsType = "vfat"; };

  # Networking
  networking.hostName = "nixos-builder";
  networking.useDHCP = true;

  # SSH for remote builder access
  services.openssh.enable = true;
  services.openssh.settings.PermitRootLogin = "yes";

  # Nix daemon configuration
  nix.settings.trusted-users = [ "root" "@wheel" ];
  nix.settings.experimental-features = [ "nix-command" "flakes" ];

  # User configuration
  users.users.root.initialPassword = "nixos";

  system.stateVersion = "24.11";
}
```

## Key Considerations
- Apple Hypervisor requires uncompressed aarch64 kernel
- virtiofs mounts may need special configuration
- podman machine expects specific partition layout
- SSH key exchange needed for remote builder auth

## References
- darwin.linux-builder: https://ryantm.github.io/nixpkgs/builders/special/darwin-builder/
- NixOS disk images: https://jade.fyi/blog/nixos-disk-images-m1/
- nixos-generators: https://github.com/nix-community/nixos-generators
close_reason: User chose nix-darwin linux-builder (nix.linux-builder.enable = true) instead of building a custom NixOS podman machine

title: Fix Nix store access in Linux sandbox
description:
## Problem
Running `nix flake check` in the Linux sandbox fails due to read-only /nix/store.

## Constraints (from ARCHITECTURE.md)
- No elevated capabilities
- Must use --userns=keep-id for correct file ownership
- Container isolation is the security boundary

## What Works
- Evaluation-only: When /nix/var/nix doesn't exist, Nix falls back to chroot store at ~/.local/share/nix/root (writable under home tmpfs)
- Shows warning but evaluation succeeds
- Builds fail because chroot store doesn't have packages from image

## What We Tried
1. **tmpfs on /nix/var/nix** - Makes Nix try real /nix/store, fails on lock files
2. **tmpfs on /nix/store/.links** - Doesn't help, lock files are next to store paths
3. **NIX_STORE_DIR/NIX_STATE_DIR** - Breaks binary cache (paths baked in)
4. **eval-store config** - Not a valid config option (CLI flag only)
5. **Kernel overlay mount** - Podman doesn't support type=overlay
6. **fuse-overlayfs** - fusermount not working in container
7. **Running as root + setpriv** - UID mapping breaks file access

## Potential Solutions to Investigate
- https://github.com/chrisguest75/nix-examples - may have container examples
- nix-user-chroot tool
- Different podman configuration
- Nix's read-only=true store option for query-only operations
- Accept evaluation-only (`nix flake check --no-build`)

## Current State
Simple setup with:
- --userns=keep-id
- --passwd-entry for correct home
- tmpfs on /home/$USER
- Chroot store fallback (warning shown, evaluation works)
close_reason: Documented Nix evaluation-only mode in sandbox-prompt.txt. Builds are not supported inside the sandbox due to read-only /nix/store - this is expected container isolation behavior. Evaluation commands (nix eval, nix flake show, nix flake check --no-build) work via chroot store fallback.

title: Update setup-deploy-key to register signing key with GitHub
description:
Modify scripts/setup-deploy-key to also add the key to the user's GitHub account as a signing key (not just as a repo deploy key).

For GitHub to show commits as 'Verified', the signing key must be on the user's account.

Add after the deploy key registration (after line 64):
```bash
# Add to user's signing keys for commit verification
EXISTING_SIGNING_KEY=$(gh ssh-key list --json title,key \
    | jq -r ".[] | select(.title == \"signing-$KEYNAME\") | .key" 2>/dev/null || true)

if [[ -n "$EXISTING_SIGNING_KEY" ]]; then
    if [[ "$FORCE" == true ]]; then
        KEY_ID=$(gh ssh-key list --json id,title | jq -r ".[] | select(.title == \"signing-$KEYNAME\") | .id")
        gh api -X DELETE "/user/keys/$KEY_ID"
        gh ssh-key add "$KEY_PATH.pub" --title "signing-$KEYNAME" --type signing
    fi
else
    gh ssh-key add "$KEY_PATH.pub" --title "signing-$KEYNAME" --type signing
fi

echo "Signing key added to your GitHub account"
```

title: Investigate Nix store solutions for container builds
description:
## Problem
`nix flake check` can evaluate but not build inside the container because:
1. Container's /nix/store is incomplete (runtime packages only, no build deps like stdenv)
2. Derivations are evaluated with /nix/store paths that don't exist
3. --store and NIX_STORE_DIR options don't change paths inside derivations

## Current workaround
- `nix flake check --no-build --impure` works for evaluation verification
- Full builds must run outside the container

## Potential solutions to investigate
1. Nix experimental local-overlay-store feature
2. Mounting host /nix/var/nix with proper isolation (not full /nix)
3. Pre-populating container with build dependencies
4. Using a remote Nix daemon/store
5. Exploring NIX_REMOTE or other env vars for store redirection

## References
- https://nix.dev/manual/nix/2.30/store/types/experimental-local-overlay-store
- The chroot store at ~/.local/share/nix/root works for fetching but not for builds

title: Fix unquoted ls output parsing in Darwin entrypoint

In the Darwin entrypoint, ls output is parsed without proper quoting, which could cause issues with special characters.

**Location:** lib/sandbox/darwin/entrypoint.sh:55-56

**Current code:**
```bash
if [ -d "$HOME/.ssh/deploy_keys" ] && [ -n "$(ls -A $HOME/.ssh/deploy_keys 2>/dev/null)" ]; then
  DEPLOY_KEY=$(ls $HOME/.ssh/deploy_keys/* | head -1)
```

**Issues:**
- $HOME not quoted inside ls command
- ls output isn't quoted and could cause issues with spaces in filenames
- Parsing ls output is generally discouraged

**Fix:** Use find or glob patterns instead of parsing ls output.

title: Fix beads sync in containers - staging mount breaks git visibility
description:
## Problem

Container staging mount for .beads isolates the JSONL from git, causing sync issues:
- Container writes to /workspace/.beads/issues.jsonl (staged copy)
- Git sees underlying host file (unchanged)
- bd sync exports correctly but git add picks up stale host file

## Root Cause

Linux/Darwin default.nix mounts entire .beads directory to staging:
```bash
BEADS_ARGS="-v $BEADS_STAGING:/workspace/.beads"
```

This isolates both beads.db (needed) AND issues.jsonl (breaks sync).

## Proposed Fix

Only stage the database, mount JSONL directly:
```bash
BEADS_ARGS="-v $BEADS_STAGING:/workspace/.beads"
BEADS_ARGS="$BEADS_ARGS -v $PROJECT_DIR/.beads/issues.jsonl:/workspace/.beads/issues.jsonl"
```

This way:
- beads.db is isolated in staging (SQLite happy)
- issues.jsonl is shared with host (git sync works)

## Files
- lib/sandbox/linux/default.nix
- lib/sandbox/darwin/default.nix
close_reason: bd sync works via beads branch - no practical issue

title: Add persistent Linux builder using macOS 26 containers
description:
## Summary

Add a persistent Linux builder mode to wrapix that can serve as a `ssh-ng://` remote builder for Nix. This enables Darwin users to build aarch64-linux packages using Apple's container CLI (macOS 26+).

## Background

- Current wrapix containers are ephemeral (`--rm` flag, PID-based names)
- Apple containers run each container as a separate lightweight Linux VM via Virtualization.framework
- This epic adds a new `wrapix-builder` command that creates a persistent container with SSH access

## Architecture

```
macOS Host
├── nix-daemon (uses ssh-ng://builder@localhost:2222)
├── Persistent Storage (~/.local/share/wrapix/)
│   ├── builder-nix/ (store)
│   └── builder-keys/
└── wrapix-builder Container (persistent, no --rm)
    ├── sshd (:22) → port 2222 on host
    ├── nix-daemon
    └── /nix mounted (persistent VirtioFS)
```

## Key Principle

Builder is completely separate from `mkSandbox` - no modifications to existing sandbox code. The builder has its own:
- Image (`lib/sandbox/builder/image.nix`)
- Entrypoint (`lib/sandbox/builder/entrypoint.sh`)
- CLI wrapper (`lib/builder/default.nix`)

## Usage (Target)

```bash
wrapix-builder start    # Start persistent builder
wrapix-builder ssh      # Connect to builder
wrapix-builder config   # Show nix.conf settings
wrapix-builder stop     # Stop builder
```

## Requirements

- macOS 26+ (Tahoe) required
- aarch64-linux only (native ARM64)
- Apple Silicon

## Reference

- Plan file: ~/.claude/plans/modular-yawning-flame.md
- Existing sandbox code: lib/sandbox/darwin/default.nix

title: Create builder entrypoint script
description:
## Summary

Create the entrypoint script for the Linux builder container that starts sshd and nix-daemon.

## File to Create

`lib/sandbox/builder/entrypoint.sh`

## Implementation

The entrypoint script must:

1. **Generate SSH host key on first run**
   ```bash
   if [ ! -f /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key ]; then
     ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -f /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key -N ""
   fi
   ```

2. **Setup builder user**
   - Create user with UID 1000 (for VirtioFS ownership)
   - Create home directory at /home/builder
   - Setup .ssh directory with correct permissions

3. **Install authorized keys**
   - Keys are mounted at /run/keys/builder_ed25519.pub
   - Copy to /home/builder/.ssh/authorized_keys
   - Set ownership to builder:builder, perms 600

4. **Configure nix-daemon**
   - Write /etc/nix/nix.conf with:
     - `experimental-features = nix-command flakes`
     - `sandbox = false` (container provides isolation)
     - `trusted-users = root builder`
     - `max-jobs = auto`
     - `cores = 0`
     - GC settings: `min-free = 1073741824`, `max-free = 3221225472`

5. **Start services**
   - Start nix-daemon in background (`nix-daemon &`)
   - Start sshd in foreground (`exec /usr/sbin/sshd -D -e`)
   - sshd must stay in foreground to keep container alive

## Reference Code

See `lib/sandbox/darwin/entrypoint.sh` for patterns on:
- User creation
- Home directory setup
- Permission handling

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Script is executable (`chmod +x`)
- [ ] sshd starts and accepts connections with key auth
- [ ] nix-daemon starts and can process build requests
- [ ] Builder user can run nix commands
- [ ] Container stays alive (sshd in foreground)

title: Create builder OCI image
description:
## Summary

Create the OCI image definition for the Linux builder container that includes sshd, nix-daemon, and all necessary configuration.

## File to Create

`lib/sandbox/builder/image.nix`

## Implementation

### Packages to Include

```nix
builderPackages = with pkgs; [
  nix                    # nix-daemon
  openssh                # sshd for remote access  
  coreutils
  bash
  gnugrep
  gnutar
  gzip
  xz
  # From base sandbox profile (lib/sandbox/profiles.nix):
  git
  cacert
];
```

### Configuration Files to Generate

1. **passwd file** - root, builder (UID 1000), nobody
2. **group file** - root, users (GID 100 with builder), nogroup
3. **sshd_config** - key-only auth, allow builder user, port 22

```nix
sshdConfig = pkgs.writeTextDir "etc/ssh/sshd_config" ''
  Port 22
  HostKey /etc/ssh/ssh_host_ed25519_key
  AuthorizedKeysFile /home/%u/.ssh/authorized_keys
  PasswordAuthentication no
  PermitRootLogin no
  AllowUsers builder
  Subsystem sftp internal-sftp
'';
```

### Image Structure

Use `dockerTools.buildLayeredImage` pattern from `lib/sandbox/image.nix`:

```nix
pkgs.dockerTools.buildLayeredImage {
  name = "wrapix-builder";
  tag = "latest";
  maxLayers = 50;
  includeNixDB = true;

  contents = [
    passwdFile
    groupFile
    sshdConfig
    pkgs.dockerTools.usrBinEnv
    pkgs.dockerTools.binSh
    pkgs.dockerTools.caCertificates
    builderEnv
  ];

  extraCommands = ''
    mkdir -p tmp var/run var/log home/builder/.ssh run/sshd etc/ssh
    chmod 1777 tmp
    chmod -R a+rwX nix/store nix/var/nix
    cp ${./entrypoint.sh} entrypoint.sh
    chmod +x entrypoint.sh
  '';

  config = {
    Env = [
      "PATH=/bin:/usr/bin"
      "NIX_SSL_CERT_FILE=/etc/ssl/certs/ca-bundle.crt"
    ];
    Entrypoint = [ "/entrypoint.sh" ];
    ExposedPorts = { "22/tcp" = {}; };
  };
}
```

## Reference Code

- `lib/sandbox/image.nix` - Main image builder pattern
- `lib/sandbox/profiles.nix` - Base packages list

## Dependencies

- Requires `wx-ope.1` (entrypoint script) to exist

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Image builds successfully with `nix build`
- [ ] Contains nix-daemon binary
- [ ] Contains sshd binary with config
- [ ] /nix/store is writable
- [ ] Entrypoint script is at /entrypoint.sh
- [ ] CA certificates are present

title: Create wrapix-builder CLI wrapper
description:
## Summary

Create the main CLI wrapper that manages the persistent builder container lifecycle (start/stop/status/ssh/config commands).

## File to Create

`lib/builder/default.nix`

## Implementation

### Function Signature

```nix
{ pkgs, linuxPkgs, skopeo }:

let
  builderImage = import ../sandbox/builder/image.nix {
    pkgs = linuxPkgs;
  };
in pkgs.writeShellScriptBin "wrapix-builder" ''
  # ... shell script
''
```

### CLI Commands

1. **start** - Start the builder container
   - Check macOS 26+ requirement
   - Ensure container system is running (`container system start`)
   - Check if container already exists
   - Generate SSH keys if missing
   - Initialize persistent nix store directory
   - Load builder image via skopeo
   - Run container with: static name, no --rm, port 2222:22, nix store mount, keys mount

2. **stop** - Stop and remove the container
   ```bash
   container stop wrapix-builder 2>/dev/null || true
   container rm wrapix-builder 2>/dev/null || true
   ```

3. **status** - Show builder status and SSH connection info

4. **ssh** - Connect to builder via SSH
   ```bash
   exec ssh -p 2222 -i "$KEYS_DIR/builder_ed25519" -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no builder@localhost
   ```

5. **config** - Print nix.conf configuration for remote builder

### Key Paths

```bash
XDG_DATA_HOME="${XDG_DATA_HOME:-$HOME/.local/share}"
WRAPIX_DATA="$XDG_DATA_HOME/wrapix"
KEYS_DIR="$WRAPIX_DATA/builder-keys"
NIX_STORE="$WRAPIX_DATA/builder-nix"
CONTAINER_NAME="wrapix-builder"
```

### Image Loading Pattern

Copy from `lib/sandbox/darwin/default.nix:58-83`:

```bash
# Convert docker-archive to oci-archive via skopeo
OCI_TAR="$WRAPIX_CACHE/builder-image.tar"
${skopeo}/bin/skopeo --insecure-policy copy \
  "docker-archive:${builderImage}" "oci-archive:$OCI_TAR"

# Load into container CLI
LOAD_OUTPUT=$(container image load --input "$OCI_TAR" 2>&1)
LOADED_REF=$(echo "$LOAD_OUTPUT" | grep -oE 'untagged@sha256:[a-f0-9]+')
container image tag "$LOADED_REF" "$IMAGE_NAME"
rm -f "$OCI_TAR"
```

### Container Run Command

```bash
exec container run \
  --name "$CONTAINER_NAME" \
  -c 4 \
  -m 4096M \
  --network default \
  -p 2222:22 \
  -v "$NIX_STORE:/nix" \
  -v "$KEYS_DIR:/run/keys:ro" \
  "$BUILDER_IMAGE" \
  /entrypoint.sh
```

## Reference Code

- `lib/sandbox/darwin/default.nix` - macOS version check, image loading, container run
- `lib/util/shell.nix` - Cleanup utilities

## Dependencies

- Requires `wx-ope.2` (builder image) to exist

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `wrapix-builder start` creates and starts container
- [ ] `wrapix-builder stop` stops and removes container
- [ ] `wrapix-builder status` shows running state
- [ ] `wrapix-builder ssh` connects to container
- [ ] `wrapix-builder config` outputs valid nix.conf snippet
- [ ] Error on macOS < 26
- [ ] SSH keys generated automatically on first run

title: Expose wrapix-builder in flake.nix
Integration test: verify linux builder works as remote builder
description:
## Summary

Create an integration test to verify the wrapix-builder works as a Nix remote builder via `ssh-ng://` protocol.

## File to Create (Optional)

`tests/darwin-builder.nix` or `tests/darwin-builder-test.sh`

## Manual Test Procedure

### 1. Build and Start Builder

```bash
# Build the wrapix-builder package
nix build .#wrapix-builder

# Start the builder
./result/bin/wrapix-builder start

# Verify it's running
./result/bin/wrapix-builder status
```

### 2. Test SSH Connection

```bash
# Connect via SSH
./result/bin/wrapix-builder ssh

# Inside container, verify:
nix --version
nix-daemon --version
whoami  # Should be "builder"
```

### 3. Test Remote Build

```bash
# Get config snippet
./result/bin/wrapix-builder config

# Test build with explicit builder (no nix.conf changes)
nix build --builders 'ssh-ng://builder@localhost:2222 aarch64-linux ~/.local/share/wrapix/builder-keys/builder_ed25519' \
  --max-jobs 0 \
  nixpkgs#hello

# Verify build succeeded
./result/bin/hello
```

### 4. Test Store Persistence

```bash
# Stop builder
./result/bin/wrapix-builder stop

# Restart builder
./result/bin/wrapix-builder start

# Verify store persists (hello should still be in remote store)
./result/bin/wrapix-builder ssh
ls /nix/store | grep hello
```

### 5. Test Cleanup

```bash
./result/bin/wrapix-builder stop
```

## Automated Test (Optional)

```bash
#\!/bin/bash
set -euo pipefail

echo "=== Building wrapix-builder ==="
nix build .#wrapix-builder

echo "=== Starting builder ==="
./result/bin/wrapix-builder start &
BUILDER_PID=$\!
sleep 5

echo "=== Testing SSH connection ==="
./result/bin/wrapix-builder ssh "nix --version"

echo "=== Testing remote build ==="
KEYS="$HOME/.local/share/wrapix/builder-keys/builder_ed25519"
nix build --builders "ssh-ng://builder@localhost:2222 aarch64-linux $KEYS" \
  --max-jobs 0 \
  nixpkgs#hello

echo "=== Stopping builder ==="
./result/bin/wrapix-builder stop

echo "=== All tests passed ==="
```

## Dependencies

- Requires `wx-ope.4` (flake integration) to exist
- Requires macOS 26+ environment with container CLI

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] Builder starts successfully
- [ ] SSH connection works with generated keys
- [ ] nix-daemon responds to build requests
- [ ] Remote build of simple package succeeds
- [ ] Store persists across container restart
- [ ] Builder stops cleanly

title: Implement container-to-host notification system
description:
## Problem
Claude Code runs inside containers but needs to trigger native notifications on the host machine (Linux or macOS).

## Solution
Unix socket + host daemon approach:
- Host runs `wrapix-notifyd` listening on a Unix socket
- Socket is mounted into containers
- Container uses `wrapix-notify` client to send notification requests
- Daemon triggers native notifications (terminal-notifier on macOS, notify-send on Linux)

## Implementation

- lib/notifyd.nix (create) - Host-side notification daemon
- lib/notify-client.nix (create) - Container-side client
- lib/sandbox/darwin/default.nix (modify) - Add socket mount
- lib/sandbox/linux/default.nix (modify) - Add socket mount
- lib/sandbox/image.nix (modify) - Include notify client
- flake.nix (modify) - Expose notifyd package

title: Add git SSH signing config to Linux entrypoint
description:
Modify lib/sandbox/linux/entrypoint.sh to configure git SSH signing using the deploy key.

Add after the existing deploy key SSH config (after line 11):
```bash
# Configure git SSH signing using deploy key
if [ -n "${WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY:-}" ] && [ -f "$WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY" ]; then
  git config --global gpg.format ssh
  git config --global user.signingkey "$WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY"
  # Create allowed_signers for signature verification
  mkdir -p "$HOME/.config/git"
  ssh-keygen -y -f "$WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY" > "$WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY.pub.tmp" 2>/dev/null || true
  if [ -f "$WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY.pub.tmp" ]; then
    echo "$GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL $(cat $WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY.pub.tmp)" > "$HOME/.config/git/allowed_signers"
    rm "$WRAPIX_DEPLOY_KEY.pub.tmp"
    git config --global gpg.ssh.allowedSignersFile "$HOME/.config/git/allowed_signers"
  fi
fi

# Enable auto-signing if requested
if [ "${WRAPIX_GIT_SIGN:-}" = "1" ] || [ "${WRAPIX_GIT_SIGN:-}" = "true" ]; then
  git config --global commit.gpgsign true
fi
```

title: Fix ~/.claude.json and ~/.claude/ mounts in Darwin VM
description:
## Problem
VirtioFS (Apple's Virtualization framework) only supports directory mounts via VZSingleDirectoryShare. The Swift runner explicitly skips file mounts (SandboxRunner.swift:150-152). This means:
- ~/.claude/ (directory) - works
- ~/.claude.json (file) - silently skipped
- ~/.claude.json.backup (file) - silently skipped

## Solution: Parent Directory Mounts with Symlinks
For file mounts, mount the parent directory to a hidden location, then symlink the specific file to its expected destination.

## Files to Modify
1. lib/sandbox/darwin/default.nix - Separate file vs directory mounts, add --file-mount args
2. lib/sandbox/darwin/swift/Sources/wrapix-runner/SandboxRunner.swift - Handle file mounts by mounting parent dirs to /mnt/wrapix/fm/<n>/, pass WRAPIX_FILE_MOUNTS env var
3. lib/sandbox/image.nix - Update entrypoint to parse WRAPIX_FILE_MOUNTS and create symlinks

## Edge Cases
- Optional mounts: Check file existence at runtime before adding to args
- Multiple files from same parent: Each gets its own mount (simple, small overhead)
- File permissions: Symlinks preserve original file permissions through virtiofs

title: Add git author env var passthrough to Darwin launcher
description:
Modify lib/sandbox/darwin/default.nix to read host's git config and pass as env vars.

Add before container launch:
```bash
GIT_AUTHOR_NAME="${GIT_AUTHOR_NAME:-$(git config --global user.name 2>/dev/null || echo 'Wrapix Sandbox')}"
GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL="${GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL:-$(git config --global user.email 2>/dev/null || echo 'sandbox@wrapix.dev')}"
GIT_COMMITTER_NAME="${GIT_COMMITTER_NAME:-$GIT_AUTHOR_NAME}"
GIT_COMMITTER_EMAIL="${GIT_COMMITTER_EMAIL:-$GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL}"
```

Then add to ENV_ARGS:
```bash
ENV_ARGS="$ENV_ARGS -e GIT_AUTHOR_NAME=$GIT_AUTHOR_NAME"
ENV_ARGS="$ENV_ARGS -e GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL=$GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL"
ENV_ARGS="$ENV_ARGS -e GIT_COMMITTER_NAME=$GIT_COMMITTER_NAME"
ENV_ARGS="$ENV_ARGS -e GIT_COMMITTER_EMAIL=$GIT_COMMITTER_EMAIL"
```

Also pass through WRAPIX_GIT_SIGN if set:
```bash
[ -n "${WRAPIX_GIT_SIGN:-}" ] && ENV_ARGS="$ENV_ARGS -e WRAPIX_GIT_SIGN=$WRAPIX_GIT_SIGN"
```

title: Investigate wrapix-builder persistence options
description:
The wrapix-builder container is currently ephemeral (destroyed on stop) due to Apple Container CLI timing issues with stop/start cycles - containers get stuck in "shuttingDown" state.

Investigate options to restore persistence for faster subsequent sessions:

1. **Volume-based persistence** - Mount a volume for `/nix/store` instead of persisting the whole container. This would preserve builds without fighting container restart mechanics.

2. **Wait for Apple CLI maturity** - The container runtime is new (macOS 26). Future updates may fix the stop/start timing issues.

3. **Hybrid approach** - Keep ephemeral containers but cache the Nix store on the host via a bind mount.

Tradeoffs documented in commit 85a540f.

title: Enable Nix builds in sandbox via fuse-overlayfs
description:
## Problem
The Linux sandbox has a read-only /nix/store from the container image. While Nix evaluation works via chroot store fallback, builds fail.

## Solution
Use fuse-overlayfs to create a writable overlay on /nix/store:
1. Add --device /dev/fuse to podman run command
2. Include fuse-overlayfs in container image
3. Mount overlay in entrypoint: lower=/nix/store, upper=tmpfs

## References
- [fuse-overlayfs](https://github.com/containers/fuse-overlayfs)
- [Nix experimental local-overlay-store](https://nix.dev/manual/nix/2.22/store/types/experimental-local-overlay-store)
- [Podman rootless overlay support](https://www.redhat.com/en/blog/podman-rootless-overlay)

## Constraints
- Must work rootless (--userns=keep-id)
- No elevated capabilities
- Container isolation remains the security boundary
close_reason: Implemented fuse-overlayfs solution: added fuse-overlayfs to profiles.nix, --device /dev/fuse to podman run, overlay mount in entrypoint.sh. All tests pass.
